content.title: Golf and wellness on the shores of the lagoon

introduction.small: Far from the hubbub of Nouméa, the Sheraton Deva Resort is perfect for unwinding with golf, walks and wellbeing. Its kids club makes it highly popular with families, too.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Golf and wellness on the shores of the lagoon

paragraphs.text:
Tucked between the green hills of Deva, a protected natural area, and the emerald waters of the lagoon, the Sheraton Resort enjoys a prime location two and a half hours from Nouméa and one and a half from the international airport. The monumental thatched wooden reception building exudes a sense of wellbeing and serenity. Tastefully furbished chalets line the beach whilst the rooms, which can be reached on foot, or by bike or electric buggy, are scattered through the sweeping grounds. Whilst the children enjoy themselves at kid's club, why not perfect your swing on the 18-hole golf course, take a country walk, enjoy a swim in the huge infinity pool, or make the most of the spa! If you're feeling peckish, you can enjoy salads, food from the grill and club sandwiches with your toes in the sand looking out to sea. Breakfast and dinner are lavish, deliciously tasty buffets, served in a spacious dining room.

Sheraton New Caledonia Deva Spa & Golf Resort

content.title: Château Royal: lagoon views

introduction.small: The Château Royal sits proudly on Pointe Magnin in Nouméa, looking out over the lagoon. Its ultra-sophisticated rooms make it the perfect place to sit back and relax.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Château Royal: lagoon views

paragraphs.text:
The impressive hangings and giant bamboo sticks in the hotel lobby beckon guests to immerse themselves in New Caledonia's European and Melanesian culture. Take the stairs from reception straight to a seaside garden – we promise you, you'll love the view! Sofas, low tables and cosy chairs make a lovely relaxed spot from which to admire the sunset. During the day, the pool bar serves cocktails beachside.
The rooms are carefully prepared for guests and offer stunning views across Anse-Vata bay. In the mornings, treat yourself to a hearty breakfast, with a buffet table stacked with croissants, fresh fruit, and freshly-prepared pancakes with New Caledonian honey. For the finishing touches to your relaxing stay at the Château Royal, unwind with a trip round the Aquatonic spa, with its 300m2 swimming pool, 12 hydromassage stations and loungers submerged in 32°C water. Not to mention the view across the lagoon!

content.title: Le Miretti Gascon: an authentic, hearty, family-run restaurant

introduction.small: At Le Miretti Gascon, a Nouméa institution established by the Miretti family, treat yourself to hearty, delicious dishes such as seafood, stuffed crab or house foie gras.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Miretti Gascon: an authentic, hearty, family-run restaurant

paragraphs.text:
Opened in 1969 and only a stone's throw from the Henry Milliard racecourse, Le Miretti Gascon is a family-run restaurant which fans of classic French cooking will love. With trocas (scallops), clams and shrimp options, the menu is a real celebration of seafood. There's fish, too: mahi-mahi (common dolphinfish), loach (grouper), picot (surgeonfish) and vinaneau (snapper). Chef Jean-Michel Parc also creates delicious dishes inspired by Gascony, a southwestern region of France. Foie gras, duck breast, tournedos rossini and frogs' legs all hold pride of place on the menu. In addition to these core dishes, which form the basis for the restaurant's reputation, the chef also creates specials with ingredients carefully selected from the market or delivered by local suppliers. Dishes are prepared with love, and served in a welcoming, friendly atmosphere. The hospitality and service are just like the cooking: warm and homely. They also offer a wide selection of dishes to take away.

Le Miretti Gascon

content.title: Au p'tit café: showcasing creativity and freshness

introduction.small: Au p'tit café is the authority on dishes which are as inventive as they are tasty. The few dishes on the chalkboard change every week, and are prepared to order.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Au p'tit café: showcasing creativity and freshness

paragraphs.text:
The terrace at Au p'tit café, which sits right in Nouméa city centre, is never empty. The studio-like kitchen is separated from the dining room by a simple window, where the team of chefs busy themselves at the ovens preparing food to amaze and delight your taste buds. Founded by chef Gabriel Levionnois, a passionate champion of local, healthy and seasonal food, the restaurant offers an ever-changing menu of four original creations, with two seafood and two meat-based dishes. There is also a vegetarian and gluten-free option. Ingredients are selected from the market and from suppliers with the utmost care. Generous yet balanced, the dishes show unrivalled creativity, with bold marriages of flavours and ingredients. So much so that you'll find yourself with an entire meal on a single plate! That being said, don't forget to save some room for the cheesecake, which is a must, or one of the pastry chef's three other creations.

Au p'tit café

content.title: La Pirogue: an invitation to adventure

introduction.small: Tucked inside the Château Royal, La Pirogue's incredible seaside surroundings, and international-inspired food mean it really stands out from the crowd.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Pirogue: an invitation to adventure

paragraphs.text:
Somewhere between French gastronomy and local cuisine, the flavours at La Pirogue will take your palate on a journey round the world. Fish is prepared five different ways: as a curry, with Lifou vanilla, Provençal-style, with coconut milk and in a creamy sauce with smoked bacon. You just can't leave without trying the restaurant's must-have dessert: the “Barre Pirogue”, with a chocolate biscuit, marzipan, a cacao crisp, a milk foam and a pear sorbet. An absolute delight!
In terms of décor, the restaurant's garden is home to a real-life wooden canoe, which was brought over from Ouen Island. The interior designers, Patricia Charles and Eric Goron, designed the scene at the request of the owner, Pascal Lafleur: “The canoe represents a journey through Melanesia, and is made of wood to signify the deep-rootedness of the Melanesian identity,” Charles explains.

content.title: Mwara: a beach worthy of Robinson Crusoe

introduction.small: With its white sandy beach, red earth and lagoon singing in subtle harmony, the palette of colours at Mwara beach is bold and striking.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mwara: a beach worthy of Robinson Crusoe

paragraphs.text:
Standing at the gateway to the “forgotten coast”, an area unspoilt by human activity and only accessible by sea, Mwara beach is a magnificent stretch of wild, exotic coastline. This fine, sandy, palm-lined beach is the perfect spot for a day relaxing, cut off from the rest of the world. It is also home to an incredible reef of brightly-coloured coral. Don't miss out on the chance to go snorkelling and get acquainted with the underwater life. It's not uncommon to see a dugong down there, which seems to have decided to make the bay its home. You can picnic in one of the equipped areas between the palm trees lining the beach. A few kilometres along the coast is the famous La Joliette shipwreck, an early 20th-century ore carrier used to transport nickel from Thio to Nouméa. Nowadays, it's a popular spot for diving and snorkelling enthusiasts. Follow the old ore roller out into the ocean to find it.

content.title: The Museum of New Caledonia: a museum of art and society

introduction.small: Museum of New Caledonia exhibitions on Kanak culture.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Museum of New Caledonia: a museum of art and society

paragraphs.text:
With an ideal location right in Nouméa city centre and only a stone's throw from Moselle Bay, the Museum of New Caledonia tells the story of the Melanesians. Although the museum embraces all South Pacific cultures, Kanak society takes centre stage. The Museum of New Caledonia offers visitors the chance to find out more about these rich cultures through countless artefacts from all over Oceania, and is home to one of the biggest collections of Kanak artwork in the world. The experience continues outdoors, too, where you can admire the native plants surrounding the central patio, or the walkway of Cook pines leading to the traditional Kanak hut in the museum's gardens.
There are also workshops, themed days, and plenty of shows on offer all year round.

content.title: Marmite et Tire-bouchon: a celebration of France

introduction.small: Delicious French food accompanied by top-quality wines is what this elegant bistro is all about. Experience the great taste of simple French cooking.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Marmite et Tire-bouchon: a celebration of France

paragraphs.text:
With its covered terrace, this intimate restaurant enjoys stunning views of the sea across Orphelinat Bay. With burgundy leather seats, stone floors and wooden tables, the simple, welcoming décor is reminiscent of many French bistros. The generously-stocked wine cellar, visible from the dining room through a glass wall, is definitely worth investigating: from Bordeaux to Burgundy, the Loire Valley and Champagne, it's full of truly great wine.
A typically-French menu is the perfect complement, featuring dishes such as ravioles de Royan, homemade foie gras, beautifully crusted beef in red wine, and duck breast. There's plenty of New Caledonian produce on offer too, with crab gratin, tuna tartare and a flaky shrimp tart all staples on the menu. Three daily specials and one dessert are the cherry on top of this tempting array of dishes. If you're finding it hard to choose, then the friendly and efficient staff will be happy to help!

content.title: The Southern Pleiades of Ouvéa: a divers' paradise

introduction.small: Dive into the heart of the Southern Pleiades of Ouvéa and head off in search of Manta rays.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Southern Pleiades of Ouvéa: a divers' paradise

paragraphs.text:
Scattered across a dozen kilometres or so, Ouvéa's southern islands are home to some incredible marine life, and an excursion is the perfect way to explore them. Tours depart from a small bay and listed nature reserve at the foot of the Lekiny Cliffs. The first stop is a “cleaning station” – a block of coral only a few metres below the surface. Turtles, sharks and Manta rays come here to rest, and provide the stage for an astonishing show. As the rays sit atop the reef, a myriad of cleaner fish descend and remove all the parasites from their mouths, gills, and skin. It's the perfect opportunity to observe these typically solitary creatures. Next, you'll head to the “garden”, a maze of reef which is home to all sorts of brightly-coloured species.
The Styx Pass, near Metouaïné island, is also the most famous dive site in the Ouvéa archipelago.

Southern Pleiades of Ouvéa,
Loyalty Islands

content.title: The comfort of tribal hospitality

introduction.small: The lodge at À La Petite Baie offers traditional tribal accommodation, complete with a private beach! Annette serves traditional, family food which she makes using local ingredients.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The comfort of tribal hospitality

paragraphs.text:
With its white sand and turquoise waters, the private beach of the À La Petite Baie lodge in Lifou is the stuff of dreams. Annette and her family have built a traditional hut on the shore, along with a pavilion and a small wooden chalet. Simple yet comfortable, they are perfect for discovering tribal life, and enjoying a stay in the magnificent Joj Bay. In the evenings, the hostess serves fresh fish or bougna, the traditional Kanak dish of cooking bananas, yams, taro and coconut milk. Sometimes she also cooks lobster or mangrove crabs – delicate dishes for the most discerning of palates!
When Annette's not in her fields, she offers her guests a trip out into the bay in her va'a (a Polynesian outrigger). It's a fantastic opportunity to see turtles and coral.

content.title: Ka Waboana Lodge: celebrating nature and Kanak culture

introduction.small: Only a stone's throw from the famous Hienghène rocks, the Ka Waboana Lodge is the perfect base from which to explore the area.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ka Waboana Lodge: celebrating nature and Kanak culture

paragraphs.text:
A fabulous mix of nature and tradition, the Ka Waboana Lodge is famous for its warm welcome and excellent food. The menu showcases Oceanian flavours with fish, shellfish, and of course Bougna, the traditional Kanak dish of cooking bananas, yams, taro and coconut milk (by request). Perched on a hill and surrounded by greenery and fruit trees, the lodge offers stunning views across the mouth of the Hienghène River. There are nine wooden chalets of various sizes – from single rooms to the honeymoon suite and family cabins – and three apartments. Spacious, peaceful, and completely refurbished, the rooms also come with a terrace and WiFi connection. In Fwaï, one of the 4 languages spoken in Hienghène, “Ka Waboana” means “forge ahead”. It's a perfect name for this welcoming lodge, which aims to give guests a taste of local culture in top-quality comfort. You're sure to experience the unexpected here.

content.title: Oro Bay and its natural swimming pool

introduction.small: Carved out of the reef and surrounded by Cook pines, there are some superb panoramic views to be had from the natural swimming pool of Oro Bay.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Oro Bay and its natural swimming pool

paragraphs.text:
The route to the bay is part of this unique area's charm. You'll need to cross a channel, ideally at low tide, then make your way through lush greenery before you finally reach this gorgeous place. The path leads to shallow, crystal-clear turquoise waters, surrounded by rocks which protect the pool from the swell of the waves. Swim in complete safety, and admire the spectacle of thousands of fabulous fish. Practically an open-air aquarium, this is the ideal spot to don your snorkelling fins and explore. The pool's surroundings are also packed with little nooks and crannies, which are perfect for sitting back, relaxing, and enjoying these idyllic surroundings. If you're not ready for the fun to stop, follow the sand from the natural pool to Oro Bay, and the Le Méridien Ile des Pins hotel. It's the perfect place for a cocktail on the beach.

content.title: Malabou Beach: a peaceful spot for all the family

introduction.small: The Malabou Beach Resort offers both comfort and family-friendly activities. With its private beach, it's the perfect base for guests wanting to explore Grande Terre.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Malabou Beach: a peaceful spot for all the family

paragraphs.text:
A charming Melanesian-style hotel, guests are warmly welcomed to the peaceful Malabou Beach Resort. The sun-drenched chalets and family suites – some with private pools – offer views over the lagoon and are surrounded by coconut palms. The terrace and safe pool also look out over the sea, and are the perfect place to take a break from activities.
There are plenty to enjoy, including free tennis, miniature golf, pétanque, ping pong, paddling and kayaking, not to mention walks around the area. There are even kids' scooters for riding back to their rooms from the restaurant. Unusual wooden puzzles are also available from the bar – as pretty to look at as they are fun to play! At meals, the resort proudly showcases seafood and traditional cuisine. Guests can enjoy lunch in the fully-equipped beach hut with their toes in the sand, and take their fill of a hearty buffet every evening.

content.title: Dreamy islands for an incredible day out

introduction.small: Whether you're a swimmer or a diver, make the most of the islands around Nouméa for some unforgettable holiday memories.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dreamy islands for an incredible day out

paragraphs.text:
Does a day or weekend getaway to a paradise island sound like heaven? Then climb aboard a water taxi and skim over the turquoise waters to the islets off the coast of the New Caledonian capital. You can wander across the white sand of unspoilt beaches on Goéland, Larégnère and Signal, go diving with turtles in the lagoon, or just sit back and enjoy a sun lounger and bar on Canard and Maître. Maître even has a hotel: perfect for a romantic getaway, with idyllic surroundings that will blow you away.
It only takes a few minutes more to reach the islet of Amédée and its protected nature reserve, famous for its abundance of underwater life. Sit back in the sun before lunch to enjoy dances and shows.
On the trip back to Nouméa, you might even be lucky enough to see the fins of a few dolphins.

content.title: Beaupré: an oasis of calm with paradise close at hand

introduction.small: On the Ouvéa atoll, the Hotel Beaupré offers guests a tranquil, restful experience minutes from Mouli Beach, where a turquoise lagoon laps at a spit of white sand.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Beaupré: an oasis of calm with paradise close at hand

paragraphs.text:
Tucked away in an oasis of green not far from Mouli Beach, one of New Caledonia's most beautiful coves, the Hotel Beaupré is a stunningly peaceful place. A flower-filled garden is home to twelve timber-covered chalets, perched on stilts, to sleep 3 or 6 – perfect for a relaxing weekend on an island known as “the closest you'll get to paradise”. Air conditioning, a spacious shower, ultra-comfortable beds, a highly practical kitchenette and a delightful terrace are just a few of the highlights that this recently-built hotel has to offer. Super friendly and surrounded by nature, the restaurant serves simple, tasty food, with produce from the lagoon taking centre stage. The hotel also offers guests the option to book excursions around the island: a visit to Anubet Cave, an outing to the shark nursery or a day's boat trip exploring the Southern Pleiades are all a must!

content.title: A taste of bush life

introduction.small: Surrounded by nature, Le Refuge du Cerf overlooks the valley from Ouaco. Chantal and Stéphane welcome guests to their lodge, and introduce them to the joys of life in the outback.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A taste of bush life

paragraphs.text:
The immense pool and breath-taking views from the chalets are a recipe for relaxation at Le Refuge du Cerf. If you're looking for a few days' getaway, this place – which is very popular with islanders – offers guests the best of outback life. Chantal and Stéphane share their day-to-day life with their guests in this remote corner of New Caledonia, tucked between Voh and Koumac. Stéphane, who loves the many deer that roam the area, can tell all sorts of stories about the animals.
Every evening, guests share a convivial meal of local food around a huge wooden table, with dishes including homemade venison sausages and ham, wild boar ragu and a squash puree. The hearty breakfast, which includes toast, papaya and mango jams, homemade pastries, muesli, fresh fruit salads and compotes, will delight even the largest of appetites. If you love beautiful walks, you can wander through the property and look for deer and peacocks! The lodge also tries to be as environmentally friendly as possible, and uses solar panels to produce its own electricity.

Le Refuge du Cerf

content.title: The Hienghène rocks: a steep upward climb

introduction.small: One of the island's natural curiosities, the Hienghène rocks span several kilometres. The most distinctive is the Nesting Hen, or “Poule couveuse”.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Hienghène rocks: a steep upward climb

paragraphs.text:
Famous for the beauty of its untamed landscapes, Hienghène is home to a number of distinctive black calcareous rocks, reaching up to 60 metres tall. In the middle of the bay sits the famous Nesting Hen.
A symbol of generosity, the legend of its appearance means it is a taboo place. It is said to have suddenly sprung out of the water to help people living in this remote area to survive.
There are panoramic viewpoints along the route, and at the entrance to the village there's a 360° view across the mountains and the lagoon, which are bathed in golden light at sunset. The viewpoint on the other side of the village overlooks the Sphinx-shaped rocky islets.
For an experience like no other you can kayak through this incredible area, all the way to the foot of the imposing Lindéralique cliffs – perfect for getting an up-close look at the grottoes and other rock formations carved out by the water over the years. You might even see some flying foxes, which have adopted this area as their favourite playground.

Lindéralique
Hienghène

content.title: The Jokin Cliffs, Lifou: prepare to be amazed!

introduction.small: To the north of the island, the Jokin Cliffs offer spectacular panoramic views across the Lifou lagoon.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Jokin Cliffs, Lifou: prepare to be amazed!

paragraphs.text:
Visit the tribal village of Jokin to admire these incredible cliffs, which soar up almost 40 metres and plunge into the crystalline waters of Jinek Bay, where the water is so clear that you can see right down to the seabed. Tucked into the dense vegetation covering the rocks are several cave burial sites for the tribe's deceased chiefs.
If you'd like a swim at the foot of the cliffs, follows the path through the forest of Cook pines, which will take you to a set of steps leading down to a platform where you can get in the water. For the ultimate experience, kit yourself out with a set of fins, a diving mask and snorkel, and explore the teeming, brightly-coloured coral reef. This is also a very popular spot with the island's youngsters, who regularly come here to compete against each other diving in.

Jokin Cliffs, Lifou
Loyalty Islands

content.title: L'Edzen: creativity on a plate

introduction.small: L'Edzen is a haven of peace and quiet just a stone's throw from Anse-Vata. Gaël Chou and his team prepare dishes overflowing with quality, joy, and creativity.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: L'Edzen: creativity on a plate

paragraphs.text:
Diners in L'Edzen's shady garden will enjoy fresh ingredients in refined and inventive fusion food: a dream come true for lovers of sweet and savoury marriages and bold flavour combinations. Must-try dishes include the Zen burger with pan-fried foie gras, and the salmon club sandwich. Aside from a few staples, dishes – which are copious and creative – change daily. In the evenings, treat yourself to the surprise menu, which must be booked 24 hours in advance. Sensational surprises are guaranteed from start to finish. L'Edzen also serves breakfast and afternoon tea, complete with a wonderful selection of fragrant teas and infusions. The homemade cakes and chocolates vary according to playful pastry chef Philippe Prévot's mood: from an Amarena cherry pudding with kava marshmallows to feuillantine or a deconstructed fruit vacherin, there are all sorts of sweet treats to choose from to round off a delicious meal.

content.title: A complete change of scenery in the far north of New Caledonia

introduction.small: Famous for its table d'hôte, white sand, salt marshes and the wild horses roaming the surrounding countryside, the Relais de Poingam is a chance to get away from it all!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A complete change of scenery in the far north of New Caledonia

paragraphs.text:
The Relais de Poingam sits in the far north of New Caledonia, right on the tip of Grande Terre. A few rustic chalets and a campsite look out over the sea. Every morning, guests are greeted by the hoofbeats of galloping wild horses. The relaxing allure of the pool, filled with water from the lagoon, is hard to resist as a perfect way to spend the day. More active types will love the walking trails around the lodge, and the beach – perfect for kitesurfing. If you're keen to explore the north of the island then a visit to the salt marshes is a must, where you can sit back and relax in a revitalising mud bath.
But the best bit about the Relais de Poingam is undoubtedly its table d'hôte. The dinner bell sounds at 8 o'clock, and guests are invited to enjoy clam carpaccio, salt-baked fish, and grilled venison, lobster, or cassava. The chefs celebrate local produce, and local women provide top-quality service.

content.title: Whale watching: a spectacular show!

introduction.small: Head off on a catamaran trip into the Southern Province to find the whales.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Whale watching: a spectacular show!

paragraphs.text:
Every year between July and September, humpback whales leave the Antarctic and flood into warmer waters around New Caledonia to breed.
Although these impressive mammals can be found throughout the archipelago, the area between Prony and Ouen Island is thought to be where the majority convene. This is a unique opportunity to see these huge cetaceans during a catamaran ride – the perfect way of getting up close without disturbing them. The boats leave from Prony Bay or Port Moselle in Nouméa early in the morning before the trade winds get up. Eat your breakfast on board and navigate through New Caledonia's Great South Lagoon. You're almost sure to come across a few dolphins along the way before the long-awaited highlight of the trip. Keep an eye on the horizon for any puffs of air, as whales spout without any warning – sometimes only a matter of metres away from the boat.

content.title: See the Heart of Voh from the sky

introduction.small: Head off to explore New Caledonia's vast range of landscapes with an ultralight aircraft experience.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: See the Heart of Voh from the sky

paragraphs.text:
Climb aboard your ultralight and take off in search of some incredible views across the island's forests, coral reef and mountains. You'll get the chance to see the Heart of Voh, an iconic site made famous by photographer Yann Arthus-Bertrand in his “Earth from Above” project, where nature itself has created a four-hectare, heart-shaped clearing in a mangrove.
This maiden flight is an intense experience where you'll get a true sense of freedom.
If you just want to see the Heart of Voh you can also go up Mt Kathépaïk, either on foot or in a 4x4. With an altitude of 406 metres, the first viewing platform is high enough for you to admire the natural formation, and the view over the lagoon is breath-taking too. That being said, the outline is even more striking when seen from the sky.

Voh

content.title: Nekweta: a surfer's paradise

introduction.small: Fall in love with the exotic, sporty vibes of Nekweta Surf Camp, only a few feet away from Roche Percée beach in Bourail.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Nekweta: a surfer's paradise

paragraphs.text:
Nekweta's chilled vibes set it apart from the rest. Tucked away in a lush tropical garden, the Melanesian hut, chalet, and wood-filled rooms blend seamlessly into their surroundings. Not far from the Roche Percée beach, which is an extremely popular spot with local surfers, the camp offers boat excursions to the coral reef, surf trips, an “eco-exploration” walk to learn about New Caledonian wildlife, and excursions to Green Island.

Sportier types can hire surfing, bodyboarding and cycling gear at reasonable prices. In the evening, guests will love Stéphanie's traditional New Caledonian food, which she makes using fresh ingredients caught and grown locally. Travellers from all walks of life are sure to love spending time in this heavenly spot.

content.title: Oure Lodge: the sand between your toes

introduction.small: Looking out over Kanumera bay to the Isle of Pines, Oure Lodge sits near a palm-lined, white, sandy beach. It's the perfect place to get away from it all.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Oure Lodge: the sand between your toes

paragraphs.text:
Enjoy an unforgettable night in the islands with a stay in a chalet at Oure Lodge. Your spacious decking and loungers, set right on the beach, are an incredible place to sit and watch the sun set over the lagoon. You could hire a kayak for an adventure around Kanumera Rock, or spend the day exploring the seabed covered in incredible coral, right outside the hotel.
After a day spent discovering the Isle of Pines, you'll love sitting back and unwinding in the colossal bathtub and the huge, soft bed. In the evenings, there are usually local fishermen to be seen on the beach, launching their small boats to go out fishing. The hotel restaurant offers a delicious menu of fresh fish, which you can enjoy out on the terrace beside the pool.

content.title: Nouméa Market: sense-ational!

introduction.small: Right at the heart of Nouméa, the market brings the city centre to life every morning, filling it with colours and flavours.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Nouméa Market: sense-ational!

paragraphs.text:
Nouméa Market in Port Moselle is the biggest in New Caledonia.
A local institution, it's extremely popular with the locals: the earlier you get there, the better!
Locally-grown fruit and vegetables fill three of the five pavilions. You'll also find plenty of delicious local specialities including honey, guava jam, hibiscus flower syrups and even pickled shrimps.
The fish market sits on the quayside overlooking the harbour, and is a must! Freshly-caught fish and shellfish fill the stalls, and with mangrove crabs, blue shrimp, lobster, mahi-mahi (common dolphinfish), tuna, parrotfish, rabbitfish, and much more, you're sure to find something you'll love!
Make sure to stop by the craft stalls outside the market, and round your basket off with costume jewellery, small decorative items and other souvenirs.
At the weekend there's even musical entertainment – make the most of it with a stop at the bar in the middle of the market!

Nouméa Market
Port Moselle

content.title: The old village of Prony: a trip down memory lane

introduction.small: At the southern tip of Grande Terre, nature is reclaiming the former village of Prony, which remains a snapshot of the past.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The old village of Prony: a trip down memory lane

paragraphs.text:
A former logging site inhabited by convicts, the village faded into obscurity when the practice of slave convoys stopped. It got a short-lived new lease of life when miners' families moved into the camp, before being abandoned for good in 1968. Although some constructions are still visible, like the powder store, the other remnants are slowly disappearing under a mass of vegetation. Giant Banyan trees cover much of the site, which was added to the French supplementary list of historic monuments in 2008. A circular walk around the vestiges of the penitentiary and through the rainforest and mining scrubland starts at Somme Bay, where you'll find out more about the prison's history. There are also breath-taking views across the bay, and a sledge that was once used to transport the felled logs. Fancy a swim? There's a hot spring not far from the village at the mouth of the Kaoris River, with facilities added long ago by the convicts. Although basic, you'll still be able to enjoy a swim in the warm water, which is known for its therapeutic properties.

Old village of Prony (Camp Sebert)

content.title: Isle of Pines: explore Upi Bay in a traditional canoe

introduction.small: There are plenty of surprises in store for you in the turquoise waters of Upi Bay.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Isle of Pines: explore Upi Bay in a traditional canoe

paragraphs.text:
Also known as “Little Ha Long Bay”, Upi Bay sits at the south-eastern end of the Isle of Pines. Every day, outrigger canoes sail back and forth across the tranquil waters, delving amongst the majestic rocks which almost seem to balance above the surface.
Step back in time by climbing aboard one of these light wooden craft, and let the lapping of the waves against the hull soothe your soul and lull your worries away. A peaceful, all-encompassing experience where it's not unusual to spot rays, turtles and dolphins, or even the pointed tips of a reef shark's fins.
The ride through Upi Bay is also a great opportunity to chat with the paddlers and other passengers.
The excursion ends with a walk through a forest of Cook pines to the natural swimming pool in Oro Bay.

Upi Bay
Isle of Pines

content.title: Blue River Provincial Park: for total immersion in nature

introduction.small: Located towards the southern end of the main island, the Blue River Provincial Park promises a total change of scenery, in surroundings that are anything but ordinary.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Blue River Provincial Park: for total immersion in nature

paragraphs.text:
The New Caledonian landscape changes completely when you head south. Gone are the white sandy beaches, replaced by red earth and vegetation straight out of the Jurassic. In the Blue River Provincial Park, the natural surroundings have remained unspoilt for millions of years. It's home to many native New Caledonian species, and is a great place for outdoor sports – you can walk, bike or kayak through the park's 9,000 hectares to explore the full extent of its beauty. Some must-see sites include the giant Kaori, Houp and Araucaria trees, which are hundreds of years old, and practically living monuments.
To the west of the park, the Drowned Forest will definitely catch your eye, with around a hundred bleached trunks rising majestically out of the man-made Yaté lake. You can kayak across this spectacular site during the day, or wait for a full-moon outing for an even more unique experience.
There's wildlife too: the park is home to an impressive kagu population, a bird which has become the national emblem of New Caledonia.
To make the most of this memorable place, why not camp out in one of the park's fully-equipped campsites?

Blue River Provincial Park
Yaté

www.newcaledonia.travel/en/great-south/yate/blue-river-park

content.title: Kô-ngé-âa-ké: the snack bar at the end of the earth

introduction.small: Formerly known as the Kou-Gny snack bar, Kô-ngé-âa-ké is known all over the Isle of Pines for its fresh lobster, served on the beach in incredible surroundings.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Kô-ngé-âa-ké: the snack bar at the end of the earth

paragraphs.text:
After a canoe trip around Upi Bay, you'll find it hard to pass up on lunch at the Kô-ngé-âa-ké snack bar. Located between the natural pool and the Le Méridien hotel in Oro Bay, diners can enjoy grilled lobster with their toes in the white sandy beach, looking out over the clear blue lagoon on a well-deserved break during an idyllic day exploring the Isle of Pines. Lobster fishing is an age-old tradition for some Kunié families (the Isle of Pines' inhabitants).

But be warned – if you' want to enjoy a lobster, you'll have to earn it! The path to the snack bar is through a channel where, depending on the tides, the water can reach up to waist height. If you don't want to get wet, you can always use the road to Le Méridien Ile des Pins. We advise booking your table a day in advance.

Kô-ngé-âa-ké

content.title: Chez Toto: a traditional bistro at the heart of the Latin Quarter

introduction.small: Authenticity, French tradition and simplicity are the bywords for this restaurant, which combines the feel of a bistro and a typical Lyon-style bouchon.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Chez Toto: a traditional bistro at the heart of the Latin Quarter

paragraphs.text:
A favourite haunt of 16th-century workers, the bouchon is a cheery inn offering meals heavily influenced by the Lyon and Burgundy areas of France – both top spots in French gastronomy. At Chez Tonto, everything from the décor to the kitchen, tiled floor, old posters singing the regions' praises, little net curtains in the windows and its leather seats, right down to the counter, makes you feel as if you're in a traditional French bistro. The dishes on offer – prime rib in shallot butter, veal head with a gribiche or ravigote sauce, homemade Dijon-style andouillette sausages, quenelles, cervelle de canut cheese dips, snails and homemade country pâté – are indulgent and delicious. Served “à la bonne franquette”, or in a plain, homely style, the restaurant's traditional craftsmanship shines through. A chalkboard featuring daily specials and fresh fish dishes, and a fabulous wine list add the finishing touches. Foodies will love this place, which offers food that is as warm and welcoming as the surroundings themselves. It's not uncommon to see diners from different tables laughing and joking with each other and with Toto, the owner, who always comes out to greet his guests during their meal.

content.title: Explore the iconic Tjibaou Cultural Centre

introduction.small: The Tjibaou Cultural Centre is a contemporary building dedicated to Kanak culture.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Explore the iconic Tjibaou Cultural Centre

paragraphs.text:
The Tjibaou Cultural Centre sits at the heart of a nature preserve, offering you the chance to completely immerse yourself in Melanesian traditions and customs. You'll be instantly mesmerised by its outdoor areas and impressive architecture. The project was written into the 1988 Matignon agreements, and awarded to the famous architect Renzo Piano, who was also behind Kansai Airport in Japan and the Pompidou Centre in Paris. Here, he combined elements of traditional Kanak huts into a much more modern design. These seemingly-unfinished buildings serve as a reminder that the Kanak culture is still evolving.
The Tjibaou Cultural Centre showcases Kanak society and displays permanent and temporary exhibitions all year round on Kanak values and knowledge. The centre is also home to a performance space where local and international artists regularly stage shows, creating an eclectic artistic and cultural line-up where visitors can enjoy traditional dances and concerts.

content.title: Relaxation guaranteed at Bétikuré

introduction.small: Tucked away from prying eyes, Bétikuré Lodge is a haven of green in Bourail, where you can experience relaxation like no other in your Jacuzzi or infinity pool.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Relaxation guaranteed at Bétikuré

paragraphs.text:
Before settling into your room, head out for a stroll through the 20 hectares of wooded parkland surrounding the Bétikuré, where palm trees and many more have stood for dozens of years. Bétikuré means “sharing the cookpot” in the Xârâcu vernacular, which means sharing meals and good times.
With plenty of space between them for extra intimacy, the lodge's six elegant mini villas include a bedroom and 65m² suite, complete with lounge and kitchen. Not to mention Bétikuré's top draw: the private Jacuzzi in every suite! If you fancy a dip, the modern infinity pool, kept meticulously by the owner, is also an excellent option. A few days' break in one of the mini villas is a chance to switch off and completely relax, and the day's enjoyment continues with the simple yet tasty table d'hôte. Specialities include a delicious filet mignon, tajine, and stuffed mangrove crab.

content.title: Giant Fern Park: one of New Caledonia's most beautiful rainforests

introduction.small: An hour and a half from Nouméa, the Giant Fern protected tropical rainforest spans an area of 4,500 hectares, covering the communes of Moindou, Farino, and Sarraméa.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Giant Fern Park: one of New Caledonia's most beautiful rainforests

paragraphs.text:
Located in the West Coast Zone (ZCO), which is listed as a UNESCO World Heritage site, the park exists to protect this incredible environment. The extraordinary natural surroundings are home to many indigenous plants and animals, and can be explored on foot, by bike, or on a footbike. The signposted trails will lead you deep into the thick forest of palm trees, orchids and – as the name suggests – plentiful tree ferns. There are little coves where you can cool off and spot hearts carved into the rock by the water, or take a break in one of the equipped rest areas or waterside to listen to the birds sing. You might even see a New Caledonian imperial pigeon, thicketbird, or the islands' national symbol, a kagu.
All the family will enjoy exploring and relaxing in the Giant Fern Park, but is also well-known as a place of study for scientists the world over.

Giant Fern Park

content.title: Terre de Soleil: an adventure in the heart of Farino

introduction.small: An hour and a half from Nouméa and close to the Giant Fern Park, the Terre de Soleil lodge is the perfect place to relax and unwind with your partner.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Terre de Soleil: an adventure in the heart of Farino

paragraphs.text:
India, Africa, Oceania… Every chalet at the Terre de Soleil lodge invites guests on a journey. Tucked away in the lush green commune of Farino, the tastefully-furnished rooms are a haven for lovers. Warming yourself by the fire during the cool season (July-August) or lounging in the private spa is the perfect way to pass the time.
After a day spent walking in the magnificent Giant Fern Park, the lodge offers guests a little bubble of peace and quiet, far from the chaos of the town. In the evenings, guests are invited to come together over a friendly aperitif, with the owner offering a glass of his home-brewed beer. Meals are prepared using fresh, local ingredients like venison, mango, papaya, and freshly-caught fish.

content.title: Discover the Amédée Lighthouse, perched upon its white sandy island.

introduction.small: About a 30-minute boat ride from Nouméa, Amédée Island is famous for its iconic 19th-century lighthouse.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Discover the Amédée Lighthouse, perched upon its white sandy island.

paragraphs.text:
Built to signal the entryway into Nouméa harbour, its metallic structure still shines as brightly as ever.
Climbing the 247 steps of the superb spiralling cast-iron staircase to the top of the lighthouse is highly recommended – you'll be rewarded with a 360° view over the lagoon's turquoise waters, the reef, and the Grande Terre mountains.
The islet, which is surrounded by a marine reserve, is also known for the beauty of what lies beneath – in addition to a myriad of fish, it's not unusual to snorkel past a few turtles. Enjoy an out-of-this-world experience with a buffet on the beach and all sorts of shows staged by the team at Mary-D.
Private yachts also regularly anchor around the islet to make the most of the gorgeous days.
Don't miss out on your chance to see if it's true what they say – that the sun always shines on the Amédée Lighthouse.

content.title: Under the Tao waterfall: an extraordinary place

introduction.small: At 200 metres high, the Tao waterfall is one of the most beautiful the island has to offer – a real must-see!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Under the Tao waterfall: an extraordinary place

paragraphs.text:
Deep in an unspoilt tropical forest, the Tao waterfall is a majestic sight. Viewed from the Oua Pandième bridge or during the short walk down to the swimming spots, it undoubtedly rivals any one of the east coast's many incredible locations. It falls on tribal land, so you'll pass through the vibrant gardens of the tribe that lives there before arriving at the start of the trail. That begins in a dense forest of tree ferns and immense roots which snake thickly over the ground. After a thirty-minute walk you'll reach the superb waterfall, where natural pools cry out for you to take a dip. You can even pass under the waterfall along a rocky ledge for an all-natural hydromassage. An oasis of calm, the waterfall's surroundings are the perfect spot for a picnic. Several more pools of turquoise water are also tucked away below the waterfall – the ideal place to try your hand at shrimp fishing.

Tao Waterfall

content.title: Plunge deep into the Poindimié coral reef

introduction.small: The underwater colours and surroundings in Poindimié are so incredible, you won't know where to look next.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Plunge deep into the Poindimié coral reef

paragraphs.text:
Several diving centres take students to explore the listed UNESCO World Heritage site of Poindimié reef. There are around fifty sites there, each more magnificent than the last. The seabed is full of grottoes, recesses, canyons and fault lines, and thick with gorgonians, nudibranchs, and other microorganisms. In the coral-lined valley of Val d'Isère, you can see leopard sharks, nurse sharks, stingrays and humphead wrasses.
From mid-July to mid-September, whales come closer to the shore – if you keep your eyes peeled, then with a bit of luck you might even spot them on a dive.
If you're more of a snorkelling fan, then the islet of Tibarama is a good option. Its shallow waters and white sandy beaches give the lagoon a clear, shimmering appearance – perfect for donning your fins, snorkel and mask and exploring the abundance of marine life.
This is one of the only places in New Caledonia that you can see the extremely rare ribbon eel.

Poindimié Reef
Poindimié

content.title: Kanua Tera: a getaway deep in southern New Caledonia

introduction.small: One hundred kilometres from Nouméa, the tranquil Kanua Tera is surrounded by the raw landscapes of New Caledonia's great south. It's the perfect place to get away from it all.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Kanua Tera: a getaway deep in southern New Caledonia

paragraphs.text:
The Kanua Tera ecolodge sits in Port-Boisé bay, combining traditional architecture with the comfort of a luxury hotel. Its magical location between the lagoon and the rainforest makes it a getaway destination like no other. The 18 beachside chalets all offer terraces looking out over the bay, for guests to make the very most of their incredible surroundings.
Down on the beach, guests can explore the seabed or go paddleboarding or kayaking from a floating pier. During the whale-watching season, the hotel will book excursions for you with professional crews. A path known as the Convicts' Path winds its way through the underbrush, following the coastline to the Port-Boisé camp where the remains of a convict logging site – including the yard and the old camp's bread oven – await you. It's an easy walk, with pools along the way to cool off in. Once you get back, enjoy a lazy afternoon on the terrace in the shade of the banyan trees, and feast on fish, shellfish and quail.

content.title: The Shabadran Terraces: an unforgettable hike

introduction.small: Located in southern Maré, the scenery of the Shabadran Terraces will take your breath away.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Shabadran Terraces: an unforgettable hike

paragraphs.text:
Take a guided tour through the gorgeous scenery around the tribal village of Kurine to one of the island's most beautiful beaches. First is a 4x4 drive through a coconut plantation, followed by a hike along unspoilt coastline and a trek up cliffs up to 140 metres high. There are plenty of viewpoints along the way where you can stop and admire the reefs – and the luckiest might also see whales during breeding season (mid-July to mid-September). After a few hours walking, the path leads to several rocky inlets opening out into an emerald sea. These white sandy beaches, hidden amidst lush greenery, will make you feel like the only ones in the world. The second bay even has a natural swimming pool carved into the coral. Before you leave, don't miss out on a coconut cut fresh from the tree by your guide. The route is quite challenging, but it's one of the most beautiful walks the island has to offer and is sure to strike a chord.

The Shabadran Terraces in Maré,
Loyalty Islands

content.title: Roche Percée: a symbol of the island

introduction.small: The surroundings of Roche Percée (or “Pierced Rock”) are astounding, not only because of its famous rock formations, but also the beauty of the beaches tucked away amidst the vegetation.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Roche Percée: a symbol of the island

paragraphs.text:
Far from the chaos of the city and only a 2-hour car ride from Nouméa, Roche Percée is a haven of peace. Right at the end of the beach, the quartz “Bonhomme” (or “Gentleman”) monolith sculpted by the waves looks out over the bay. There's also a tunnel here, which leads to Turtle Bay. As the name suggests, this peninsula is a key nesting site for big-headed turtles. You can see the eggs hatching and the baby turtles making their way towards the ocean between December and February.
There are plenty of things to do at Roche Percée: it's the only surfing spot in New Caledonia, and also offers plenty of walks where you can unwind surrounded by nature.
Explore the various trails leading through a forest of cycas trees and Cook pines to the thick, shady cluster of mangrove trees at its centre, and enjoy the magnificent views over the delta from the path between the 3 bays. It is here, seen from the sky, that you'll discover that it's actually the shape of a Manta ray.

Roche Percée
Bourail
